comment: It can end up creating a bunch of unnecessary layers for me. I prefer when the code is all in one place so I can better picture what is happening rather than having to route through multiple connected files.
Not sure I agree. I’d rather debug through multiple small files than one large one. Makes a project more scalable in the long run.

I think it totally depends on your experience. Sequelize is perhaps easier for someone with no SQL knowledge to grasp and connect to a JS syntax. For very complex queries I can see where sequelize with little SQL knowledge could be frustrating, and where someone with more SQL experience would rather just skip it altogether. I suppose that is where sequelize.literal is useful.
Do you like microwave meals or to cook from scratch?

You see that is where I take issue. A microwave meal is just plug and play, where as sequelize still requires you to wrap you head around a syntax and pore through documentation to add code to multiple files when I could achieve the same outcome with a single statement.
And microwave meals are really not healthy
How does someone writing sequelize or SQL have time to cook?

Using an ORM has it’s pros and cons. There are some performance sacrifices on a large scale, but it does have the benefit of keeping everything in the same language. There are certainly some limitations when it comes to more complex queries.
